TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in the city of GPE , GPE ( GPE ) .
CARDINAL . The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

CARDINAL . The full name of the applicant , a NORP citizen of NORP origin , is , in LANGUAGE , “ PERSON ” ( PERSON ) . PERSON is the first , or given , name ; PERSON is the surname , while PERSON is the “ patronymic ” ( otchestvo in NORP , po - bat'kovi in GPE ) - in other words , a second given name , derived from the father 's given name and the appropriate gender suffix .

CARDINAL . The applicant was born on the territory of former NORP GPE . His birth certificate was issued in the NORP language . On DATE , by then living on the territory of former NORP GPE , the applicant received his first NORP passport ( паспорт гражданина ORG ) , issued in NORP and NORP . According to the applicant , in the NORP version , his name and patronymic were transliterated from LANGUAGE as “ ORG ” ( PERSON ) . According to the Government , the applicant 's name and patronymic could not appear in the NORP version other than in its NORP form – “ PERSON Володимирович ” ( ORG ) , since the rules at that time knew no exceptions . ( However , neither party could submit any document to prove their assertions , because no archives or copies of that passport exist any longer ) .
CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the applicant lost his passport and , given a lack of new NORP passport forms , he was issued with a special temporary identity certificate drafted in NORP .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant applied for and received a NORP citizen 's internal passport ( паспорт громадянина GPE ) from ORG in GPE управлiння PERSON внутрiшнiх справ PERSON , “ the Directorate ” ) . PERSON of this document is drawn up in NORP , and the applicant 's given name and patronymic appear in their NORP form “ PERSON Володимирович ” ( ORG ) . However , on page CARDINAL of the passport , which is in LANGUAGE , his whole name is written in its original NORP form .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the applicant applied to the ORG for a NORP citizen 's passport for travel abroad ( паспорт громадянина GPE для виїзду за кордон ; an “ external passport ” ) . It appears from the case file that , when submitting his application , the applicant was obliged to complete and sign a form on which he gave his given name as ORG . This “ PERSON ” form of his given name ( “ ORG / DMYTRO ” ) appears on the first page of the passport , which is in GPE and LANGUAGE ; there is no mention of the patronymic . The applicant challenged this “ NORP ” by means of an internal appeal , submitted to the management of the ORG 's local branch , which dismissed it .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the applicant appealed to ORG , PERSON . He submitted that there had been a violation of his right to the integrity of his given name , and asked the court to order the authorities to issue him with a new passport and to pay him CARDINAL hryvnas for non - pecuniary damage .

CARDINAL . After adversarial proceedings , the court dismissed the appeal in a judgment of DATE . The judgment noted that the disputed spelling complied with the relevant regulations , which stated that all entries on the first page of an external passport were to be in GPE and LANGUAGE . The court also noted that all of the principal entries in such a passport were to follow the model of the corresponding entries in the internal passport issued to the same person . On the first page of his internal passport , the applicant 's given name had been entered as ORG ; accordingly , this spelling was also to be used in the external passport . In addition , the court pointed out that the applicant himself had written his given name as ORG on the passport application form ; consequently , his objections were unfounded .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed to ORG . He vehemently denied that he had used the form ORG on the application form . In his opinion , this was a manifestly erroneous finding by the court of first instance , since he had , without question , indicated that his given name was PERSON and not PERSON .
CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE , ORG dismissed the appeal and upheld the findings of the court of first instance .
CARDINAL . The applicant subsequently made several applications to the prosecution service and the President of ORG for supervisory review of the final decision , all of which were dismissed .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the applicant submitted an internal appeal to the head of the ORG 's local branch . He challenged the fact that his given name and patronymic had been translated into NORP ; in particular , he alleged that , even on the NORP page of the passport , these ought to have appeared in their original form merely transliterated into the NORP alphabet , not replaced by their NORP equivalents . Consequently , according to the applicant , his name ought to have been written on page CARDINAL of the passport as “ LOC ” ( PERSON ) , since the NORP grapheme ' И ' reads as [ i ] in NORP but as [ y ] in GPE . The appeal was dismissed .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the applicant lodged an application with ORG , PERSON , for an order requiring the authorities to issue him with a new passport in which his given name and patronymic would be written in their original form on both the NORP and NORP pages . In his submissions he emphasised , inter alia , that he belonged to the NORP minority and that consequently , under LAW of LAW , he was entitled to use the original , NORP form of his name . According to the applicant , when entering his given name and patronymic on page CARDINAL of the passport , the authorities would have been entitled to transliterate them into the NORP alphabet , but they had not been entitled to replace them with NORP equivalents .

CARDINAL . After adversarial proceedings , ORG dismissed the appeal as unfounded . The judgment noted that the disputed passport had been drawn up in compliance with ORG , which stated that the holder 's personal data were to appear “ in NORP and in NORP ” . Finally , the court pointed out that page CARDINAL of the passport had been drawn up in NORP , and that all the elements of the applicant 's name appeared on it in their original form ; accordingly , there had been no violation of the applicant 's fundamental rights .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed against this judgment to ORG which , in a judgment of DATE , also dismissed his appeal . In ORG opinion , the provision by which the holder 's personal data were to appear “ in NORP and in NORP ” indeed meant that the given name , patronymic and surname were “ to comply with the requirements of the NORP language , in application of the rules governing literary translation ” . Like ORG , ORG added that there had been no violation of the right to the integrity of one 's name in the present case , since all the entries on page CARDINAL of the passport had been in NORP .

CARDINAL . As with his external passport , the applicant made several applications to the prosecution service and the President of ORG for a supervisory review of the final decision . These appeals were all dismissed .
CARDINAL . The relevant parts of LAW provide :
“ The official language in GPE is GPE .
The ORG ensures the comprehensive development and functioning of the NORP language in all spheres of social life throughout the entire territory of GPE .
In GPE , the free development , use and protection of NORP , and other languages of the national minorities of GPE , is guaranteed ... ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the PERSON provides :
“ Every NORP citizen is entitled to have a surname , given name and patronymic [ corresponding to his or her national origin ] .
ORG are entitled , in accordance with the rules in force , to revert to their [ original ] surname , given name and patronymic .

ORG whose ethnic tradition does not involve the use of a ' patronymic ' [ po - bat'kovi ] are entitled to indicate only their surname and given name in [ the ] documents ; their birth certificate [ may ] indicate the surnames of the father and of the mother . ”

CARDINAL . NORP citizens normally have CARDINAL passports , each of which has a distinct function . The internal passport ( also called the “ NORP citizen 's passport ” ) is the basic identity document , proving the holder 's identity in all administrative and socio - economic relations throughout the country . In contrast , the external passport is a travel document for use abroad .

CARDINAL . A Regulation concerning the procedure for examining applications for a change of surname , given name or patronymic from citizens of GPE was approved by ORG on DATE .

CARDINAL . According to that ORG , any citizen of GPE who has reached the age of DATE can apply for a full or partial change of name to the civil status registration department responsible for the district in which the individual resides . The applicant must pay a fee and provide a birth certificate and photograph and , if he or she is married and has children , the marriage certificate and the birth certificates of the children .

CARDINAL . The civil status registration department verifies the documents and their archived records and sends the file to the local police department . Within DATE , the latter shall make the necessary checks of the person 's identity in order to prevent abuse of the procedure by people fleeing from justice , avoiding the payment of child maintenance , or pursuing other fraudulent purposes . The case file is then returned to the civil status registration department together with an opinion on the question of the proposed change of name . In case of police objections or if the applicant is under criminal investigation , on trial or convicted , the civil status department will refuse the application . This refusal can be challenged in the courts .
CARDINAL . The whole procedure should normally take DATE , unless there is a need to restore some lost archive documents concerning the civil status of the applicant .
CARDINAL . If the application for a change of name is granted , the individual must change the official documents , like the passport , within DATE .
CARDINAL . ORG Framework Convention for ORG was opened for signature on DATE and entered into force in respect of GPE on DATE . LAW provides as follows :

“ The Parties undertake to recognise that every person belonging to a national minority has the right to use his or her surname ( patronymic ) and first names in the minority language and the right to the official recognition of them , according to modalities provided for in their legal system . ”
Paragraph CARDINAL of the explanatory report to LAW states :

“ In view of the practical implications of this obligation , the provision is worded in such a way as to enable Parties to apply it in the light of their own particular circumstances . For example , Parties may use the alphabet of their official language to write the name(s ) of a person belonging to a national minority in its phonetic form . Persons who have been forced to give up their original name(s ) , or whose name(s ) has ( have ) been changed by force , should be entitled to revert to it ( them ) , subject of course to exceptions in the case of abuse of rights and changes of name(s ) for fraudulent purposes . It is understood that the legal systems of the Parties will , in this respect , meet international principles concerning the protection of national minorities . ”
